University of Leicester https://www2.le.ac.uk These are the search results for the query, showing results 61 to 68. Biologists identify nerve cells that make locusts form gangs https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2014-archive-1/december/bugs-life-the-nerve-cells-that-make-locusts-2018gang-up2019 Biologists from Universities of Leicester and Sydney reveal behavioural changes in locusts through serotonin-producing cells A team of biologists has identified a set of nerve cells in desert locusts that bring about \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdgang-like\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd gregarious behaviour when they are forced into a crowd.

Dr Swidbert Ott from the Department of Biology, working with Dr Steve Rogers at the University of Sydney, Australia, has published a study that reveals how newly identified nerve cells in locusts produce the neurochemical serotonin to initiate changes in their behaviour and lifestyle.

Computer reconstruction of nerve cells in a desert locust that produce the neurochemical serotonin. The yellow cells increase their serotonin content within an hour of exposing a locust to any of the social stimuli that induce gregarious behaviour. \ufffd\ufffd University of Leicester
Locusts are normally shy, solitary animals that actively avoid the company of other locusts. But when they are forced into contact with other locusts, they undergo a radical change in behaviour \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd they enter a \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdbolder\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd gregarious state where they are attracted to the company of other locusts. This is the critical first step towards the formation of the notorious locust swarms.

Dr Ott said: \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdLocusts only have a small number of nerve cells that can synthesise serotonin. \ufffd\ufffdNow we have found that of these, a very select few respond specifically when a locust is first forced to be with other locusts. Within an hour, they produce more serotonin.

\ufffd\ufffd\ufffdIt is these few cells that we think are responsible for the transformation of a loner into a gang member. In the long run, however, many of the other serotonin-cells also change, albeit towards making less serotonin.\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd

Serotonin has important roles in the brains of all animals that include the regulation of moods and social interactions.\ufffd\ufffd

In humans, there are strong links between changes in serotonin and mental disorders such as depression and anxiety.

The paper, \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdDifferential activation of serotonergic neurons during short- and long-term gregarization of desert locusts\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd, published in the academic journal Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences, can be found here.

  • Press Release
]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Magazine:Research Magazine:Staff Biology 2014-12-17T12:50:00Z Blog Entry Banana genome sequence unzipped https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/blog/2012/july/banana-genome-sequence-unzipped Leicester botanist contributes to important breakthrough with far-reaching consequences. Last week the banana became the latest organism to have its entire genome sequenced, with the help of a Leicester academic. Professor Pat Heslop-Harrison from our Department of Biology was among the researchers contributing to a paper published in Nature.

Bananas are one of the world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds most important crops but present special problems for geneticist because they are sterile: there are no seeds in domesticated banana strains. The wild variety sequenced, Musa acuminate malaccensis, is one of three ancestral subspecies contributing to the genetic make-up of Cavendish, the triploid strain which accounts for virtually all commercially grown bananas

In an interview with the LA Times, Professor Heslop-Harrison outlines some of the oddities in the genome, including three historical duplications of chromosomes and the incorporation of genetic material from banana streak virus.

The French-led study also involved Swiss, Czech, American, Australian and Dutch researchers.

  • The banana (Musa acuminata) genome and the evolution of monocotyledonous plants (doi:10.1038/nature11241)

For more on Professor Heslop-Harrison\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds banana research, see:

  • Leicester botanist explains dangers of disease to banana production
  • Yes we have no bananas: Leicester biologist presents at global conference
Venn diagram showing distribution of shared gene families (sequence clusters) among M. acuminata (banana), P. dactylifera (date palm), A. thaliana (thale cress), O. sativa (Asian rice), S. bicolor (sorghum) and B. distachyon (purple false brome).
]]> No publisher mjs76 Magazine:Staff Botany Biology Genetics Magazine:Research Magazine:Student 2012-07-16T14:16:28Z Blog Entry 'Unusual Vegetables From Seed' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2014/february/unusual-vegetables-from-seed Tuesday 18 February at 7:30pm in the Ken Edwards Lecture Theatre 2 Founder of Original Touch World Garden Seeds, Samantha Ford's gardening talks embrace the modern culture of gardening as a way to eat healthily and interact in a more sympathetic way with our environment.

Samantha has an impressive knowledge of the origins of many of our more familiar vegetable varieties, as well as others which are more unusual. Her research has also uncovered many forgotten elements of the folklore surrounding what we eat, which will throw a whole new light on your humble vegetable garden or allotment.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Event:Lecture Biology College:MedBioPsych Botanic Garden Magazine:Staff 2014-02-18T19:30:00Z UoL Event 'The Way We Gardened Then' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2013/november/the-way-we-gardened-then Thursday 14 November at 7:30pm in the Ken Edwards Lecture Theatre 3 This talk builds on Doug\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds passion for collecting and reading old gardening magazines, brochures and books. How did we garden over 60 years ago and how much have things changed from the humble shed, to the flower show and of course the very latest products and devices to make gardening easy?

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Biology College:MedBioPsych Event:Lecture Botanic Garden Magazine:Staff 2013-11-14T19:30:00Z UoL Event 'The Royal Gardens, Windsor' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2014/january/the-royal-gardens-windsor Thursday 23 January at 7:30pm in the Ken Edwards Lecture Theatre 3 Jeff trained at Windsor Castle, and has worked as lecturer and designer. He has a particular interest in historic gardens. He has been a judge for East Midlands in Bloom for 25 years, and is co-Vice-Chair of Britain in Bloom.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Event:Lecture Biology College:MedBioPsych Botanic Garden Magazine:Staff 2014-01-23T19:30:00Z UoL Event 'Texture & Foliage' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2014/march/texture-foliage Thursday 20 March at 7:30pm in Ken Edwards Lecture Theatre 3 Annual General Meeting

Brian is a well-known nurseryman and plant enthusiast with a passion for collecting rare and unusual plants, mainly herbaceous perennials and grasses. In this illustrated talk, Brian shows how foliage is as important as flowers in the garden.

]]> No publisher ap507 Magazine:Student Biology College:MedBioPsych Event:Lecture Botanic Garden Magazine:Staff 2014-03-20T19:30:00Z UoL Event 'Rho GTPases: signalling in cell adhesion and migration' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2014/february/rho-gtpases-signalling-in-cell-adhesion-and-migration Frank and Katherine May Lecture Theatre, Henry Wellcome Building - 07 Feb 2014, 12:30PM - 01:30PM Lecture title - Rho GTPases: signalling in cell adhesion and migration.

]]> No publisher User Submitted Biology College:MedBioPsych Event:Lecture 2014-02-07T12:30:00Z UoL Event 'Garden Folklore' https://www2.le.ac.uk/news/events/2013/december/garden-folklore Thursday 5 December at 7:30pm in the Ken Edwards Lecture Theatre 3 A second- generation gardener, Stuart trained at Stapeley Water Gardens, then at Kew. He has lectured at two horticultural colleges and is now a consultant and lecturer. A popular speaker, he is author of An Encyclopaedia of Plants in Myth, Magic, Legend and Lore, published by Robert Hale Ltd, 2011.
